posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: In the 10,000 Lakes Regional playoffs, our team experienced a problem where the 5V rail on our Robotic Input/Output (RIO) Digital I/O (DIO) ports failed during a match, possibly due to a collision with an opponent's defense bot. We may not pursue replacing the affected components immediately, as the next robotic controller update is expected soon. Additionally, we discovered that our Voltage Regulator Module (VRM) can effectively substitute for the power function we lost, so we are considering using that as an alternative solution. Has this been a common issue others have faced before?

posts.name: Aaron
posts.cooked:
10,000,000 lakes?

Anyway, are any of the status lights different? Are there any faults for the RIO on the Driver Station?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 4269 Student Captain and Electrical Lead

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked: This can happen if the 5V rail is shorted to ground or another source, such as 12V. The power source is not particularly fault-tolerant, leading to issues like metal shavings from drilling while installed in a robot, which can cause this problem. Some users have resolved the issue by thoroughly cleaning their devices, while others found that the damage to the source circuit was permanent, requiring them to find an alternative 5V power source.

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: There are no status lights; the only issue with the RIO is the 5V.

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: We had metal shavings at one point, which we then vacuumed out. Although you might be right, the issue was eventually resolved, but it‚Äôs still concerning that there could‚Äôve been delayed, permanent damage.

We‚Äôve encountered an issue with a Rio that experienced a problem with its 5V rail, though this is somewhat unrelated to the current matter. At our first compound, we installed some limit switches and connected one wire to the signal and another to the 5V supply. Normally, this shouldn‚Äôt function properly due to an internal pull-up resistor on the DIO, but surprisingly, it worked. However, during practice, the Rio transitioned to an unrecoverable error before ultimately showing a power fault during debugging.
What is your power status light? If it‚Äôs red, it means that you have a chip in the ports shorting it. If it‚Äôs green, it‚Äôs something else.

link_counts.title: Status Light Quick Reference ‚Äî FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Issac Woo
posts.cooked: I also want to offer this: try unscrewing your roboRIO apart, carefully, and use isopropyl alcohol to clean up anything inside there as well. You'll be surprised how much dust is in there!

Something like that happened to us. Our RSL port just completely died randomly during competition. All the ports on the rio were covered with electrical tape, so nothing should have been able to get in and damage it.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
This can happen if the 5v rail is shorted to ground or another source, such as 12v. The power source is not particularly fault-tolerant, often resulting in metal shavings from drilling while installed on the bot, which can cause this issue.  

I‚Äôm curious about devices that are more fault-tolerant than the roboRIO. They typically continue operating on a specific pin even with a direct short. The fact that debris can usually be cleared without releasing the "magic smoke" suggests it is more fault-tolerant than most devices.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Off-highway vehicle controllers designed for the consumer market differ slightly from industrial versions, though they share a similar design concept with the roboRIO. Every input/output (I/O) pin is designed to be short-to-high and short-to-ground fault tolerant, even when connected to external 5V sources, ensuring protection against battery shorts. In most cases, if a fault is detected, the pin is reset to a neutral or off state to prioritize safety considerations.

There are scenarios where simultaneously shorting one pin to high voltage and another to ground could create a dead short across the intrinsic body diode of an output driver chip, potentially damaging it. This situation typically requires multiple simultaneous failures. I‚Äôve also encountered instances where metal shavings from improper soldering caused issues, and some people have managed to fix these by cleaning.

Additionally, I‚Äôve observed that students sometimes inadvertently cause problems by shorting supply rails. While every component has specific design limitations that must be respected to prevent damage, the roboRIO represents an improvement in this regard. I‚Äôm impressed by what I‚Äôve heard about the new '27 control system, which claims 100% short-to-high (S2H) and short-to-ground (S2G) pin testing, which seems appropriate for the FIRST teaching environment.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: Did you know you can jump-start a medium-sized motor grader using an arc welder? That kind of fault-tolerant setup sounds like something that would bring a slight smile to someone‚Äôs face. To the person who posted, regarding your RIO with the fried 5V rail‚Äîit‚Äôs the second such issue your team has encountered in the past four years, and despite efforts to resolve it, it remains a recurring problem. It seems like you might soon have new challenges to complain about instead! üòä

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked:
10,000,000 lakes, you know, I had this friend in college who insisted Wisconsin has more lakes than Minnesota.

OP, there‚Äôs a good chance you have a short somewhere. Most (or possibly all) of the 5V pins on a RIO come from the same internal rail, so you can‚Äôt just unplug a few things. Unplugging everything from the RIO except for power, check if you can measure 5V on it.

If you see 5V, something you plugged into the RIO is shorting it out. Don‚Äôt plug anything back in until you identify what caused the short. RIOs are generally resilient compared to, say, a motor controller, but they‚Äôre still delicate.

If you don‚Äôt see 5V with everything unplugged, replace the RIO and test it separately. Before putting in a new RIO, inspect the wiring that was connected to it‚Äîthere could be a short in your wiring that damaged the 5V rail, and you wouldn‚Äôt want to risk harming another RIO.

Metal shavings are usually the culprit in this scenario. The absolute worst thing you can do here is continue to use the RIO without fixing it. The concern is that metal shavings could wander elsewhere and damage the RIO entirely. After checking your wiring, swap the RIO, disassemble the faulty one, and clean it. For ESD safety, I‚Äôd avoid using brushes or cloths unless there‚Äôs an abundance of debris and no other option.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
I may be mistaken, but if I recall correctly, about two years ago when we opened up a Rio with a fried 5V bus from a short circuit, most of the board was conformal-coated to a decent thickness.

I completely agree to stop using it and address the issue, but I'm wondering if metal shavings deeper within the bus could actually be a problem at all.

I remember that the conformal coating wasn't covering the I/O pins themselves, but it did start again just a few millimeters beyond the mechanical openings.

Or perhaps I'm mixing this up with another controller I've taken apart recently‚ÄîI can't say for sure.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked: Everyone is surprised at the 32V jump-start voltage levels for a 12V system, or charging system load dump transients! Who knows what someone might rig up out in the field to try to get themselves home‚ÄîI‚Äôve heard of welders being used before but never seen it.

posts.name: Dan Nichols
posts.cooked:
Quite to the dismay of automotive electronics engineers everywhere‚Äîand Brandon Hjelstrom‚Äîon a separate note, I sure hope the new Mobile Robot Controller is designed like a potted unit. The roboRIO has been particularly problematic due to its large gaps around the DIO port, leading to potential material sneaking through the small gaps around other ports. Taping over everything still results in internal shorts, possibly due to tiny particulates generated by the elevator.  

We already knew that the product wouldn‚Äôt include sealed industrial or automotive connectors, which is somewhat disappointing, especially since FIRST teams rarely use such components. However, switching to Molex SL connectors instead of a header strip reduces the risk of the case having a gaping hole.  

It‚Äôs unclear why the RIO specifically has this issue‚Äîperhaps the conformal coating is too thin. We weren‚Äôt just experiencing a 5V short; the device didn‚Äôt even boot until we disassembled it and cleared out the blown fuses.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 548 Robostangs Electrical & Pneumatics Lead Mentor

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: We finally got back to the shop yesterday. Apparently, there was a metal shaving that we missed at the compressor, and it had become stuck deep inside. We used compressed air in the shop to blow it out, and the problem has now been resolved.

posts.name: Michael Tucker
posts.cooked: The Rio has internal overcurrent protection on its 5V DIO ports (rated at 1A) and 6V PWM ports (rated at 2.2A). This design is intentional to prevent damage to electronics caused by metal shavings from these rails. Additionally, we take extra care to seal all exposed openings as much as possible. Between uses, we also clean the Rio by opening the case and removing any debris that may have accumulated inside. Interestingly, even units that appear well-sealed can sometimes acquire debris internally over time.
